There are actually some great music stores in NYC where digging could still be done. Places like Academy Records and Other Music are still thriving, as well as new shops like Rough Trade. As for discovering music online, a great way to "dig" is to go through the recommended tabs for artists you already enjoy in apps like Spotify and Pandora. I find that I still stumble across quite a bit of music I have never heard before.

But where did the people Hicklin admires find their favorite books in the first place? And where do the people whose taste I admire find the books they recommend to me? Where do I find the books I recommend to my friends? Where do we find those fascinating books in subjects we don't normally read? We will always need bookstores.

When I was younger, there were many sheet music stores in New York City. I spent many hours browsing in the stacks, and as a result, found interesting, under-performed, or unknown works to program in my concerts. My performances brought these works to the notice of other musicians, leading to more performances.

There are no New York City music stores in which to browse anymore. Where do we find music that is not in the mainstream now? People say, "You can find anything online," and that's true ... if you know what you're looking for, and if someone has already put it online. What you can't find is what you aren't looking for, because you don't know it exists.

The closing of the music stores of New York City made concerts less innovative and interesting, and the closing of bookstores will make reading less comprehensive and interesting.

Just a quick affirmation of the bona fides here. mjb has been singing the praises of this show from the git-go. The gathering "hype," as Craig W characterizes it in a comment above, is gradually catching up with mjb's authentic original take on the event. Sight unseen, I'd like to reassure Craig that the varied, high-profile attention being showered on the show is not just gratuitous commercial glitz: This thing is the real deal, with the potential, at least, to open fresh channels of conception and expression on Broadway and to leave an enduring mark on American theater in general. For my part, I share D.H. from Philly's affection for "spoken word" and am not really looking forward to sitting through the video of the show when it appears; but I'll do it, on the strength of the recommendations that come pouring in from all sides of the current cultural terrain. mjb has it right: This one is special.

Making More Space in a One-Bedroom Apartment
July, 24th 2015
Michelle Higgins
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/26/realestate/making-more-space-in-a-one-...®ion=top-news&WT.nav=top-news

This article is interesting in two different ways. First, I think it is an excellent idea for those looking to renovate their one bedroom apartment to something more space savvy. I myself wouldn't have thought about this but it is smart and saves a lot of money. In the city of Detroit there are a abundance of One bedroom apartments available but not two. So it would seem that this article would be useful for those looking to live in cities that are all over the country. On the other hand, the article mentions how practical this is for families and I disagree. "Raising children in the dining room may not seem like the American dream of home-ownership. But in New York City’s tight real estate market, the reconfigured one-bedroom may be a way for buyers to move up, if only a half-step." A small cramped space where they can barely move around for what reason other than to live in New York. New York is an enormous city and is already over populated to say the least. People could choose to leave the city and raise their families in a spacious environment. This quote itself just proves that people would choose to raise a child in a manner that isn't ideal to save money and to live the city and that to my is wrong.

Freely choosing to have a child or not starts when you choose to have sex. If your "choice" is unprotected sex, or failing to use a condom because "it doesn't feel as good" -- then you are CHOOSING to risk pregnancy.

While a small number of abortions occur to due birth control failures, the reality is that 90% or more are done on healthy young women with healthy normal pregnancies because that woman decided not to use birth control.

Our economy is completely messed up, when a couple can't buy a two bedroom home for a million dollars but paying someone $15 an hour is too much. Think this through folks. Over a million dollars for a one bedroom apartment proves economic disparities are hurting people from the high middle on down.

I can't help but think these talented people could find better lifestyles at a more affordable rate elsewhere. This market is too out of control to be sustained.
